image_analysis.description: A high-quality scan of a two-page spread from a printed book. The left page (200) is partially obscured by the book's gutter, while the right page (201) is fully visible. The right page begins with 'CHAPTER 53'. A document control number is visible at the bottom right of the image.
image_analysis.layout: Two-page book spread. The left page shows the end of a chapter, and the right page begins a new one. Text is arranged in a single column on each page, with page numbers at the bottom. A document identifier is stamped at the very bottom of the image.

CHAPTER 53

Sheriff Ric Bradshaw: June 2015

Our job,” says Ric Bradshaw, “was to make sure nobody
killed him.”
Sheriff Bradshaw could have stepped off the set of a
Western. Imposingly tall, with his cowboy hat, Kurt Russell
mustache, and slow, southern drawl, he looks exactly like an
old-school law officer—the kind you once would have found
patrolling the streets of Tombstone, Deadwood, or Dodge City.
He’s been a lawman for forty-four years, eleven of which have
been spent as the head of the county’s jails. As a rule, he doesn’t
talk to the media, and today, as he talks about Jeffrey Epstein,
he’s clearly uncomfortable, fidgety, and ill disposed.
But here in his wood-paneled office on the first floor of the
Gun Club, Bradshaw remembers Epstein quite well.
“We have a thousand sexual predators in the county,” he
says. “When he arrived here, he was one of them. He definitely

document_metadata.subject: Interview with Sheriff Ric Bradshaw regarding Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration.

notes: The document is a scan of pages 200 and 201 of a book. The text on the left page (200) is partially cut off by the book's binding. The name 'ATTERSON' at the top of the left page is likely the end of a longer name, such as 'PATTERSON'.
